Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: General Economics intro class
I learned about introductory statistics and R programming.

This is by far the worst class I have taken at Yale. I taught myself how to use R outside of class time and I borrowed a textbook from a student who had taken ECON 131 to learn the statistical material. I would honestly say that I learned absolutely nothing from going to lecture.
I learned a-lot about reading data skeptically and how to quantitatively assess situations (ex: hypothesis testing, regressions, omitted variables). Also, gained significant R knowledge!
Strengthened my statistics background by going into regression in depth. Also introduced me to R, Latex, and coding in general.
I learned basic statistics.

Econometrics covers probability, random variables, statistical measuring and analysis techniques, and hypothesis testing. It's a score of statistical reasoning in one semester. It improves technical skills and objectivity.

This was the most informative and worthwhile class I took this semester. Although it won't be easy, you will leave with a wider array of knowledge of statistics, R, and real world data analysis than when you came in. The R skills are tremendously useful and learning about how to analyze experiments and data is always helpful.
Econometric models including linear regression, probability statistics, omitted variables, etc.

I learned fundamental concepts of probability and statistics and how these concepts could be applied to real world economic studies. I also learned how to use R to explore different data sets using the models and skills we developed in class.
Statistics, econometrics

-learned basic skills in R
- developed an understanding of statistical analysis for the first time 
-hypothesis testing, linear regression, diff-in-diff, treatment effects, reg discontinuity, instrumental variables, machine learning

I got a great introduction into the foundations of data analysis using several real-life case studies in addition to theory. I learned what to look for when examining data and how to interpret results fully, both in the context of econometrics and otherwise.
This course did a great job of teaching basic statistics and applying those concepts to economics while using R.
statistical analysis, pretty cool applications at the end but a lot of information was packed in at the end.
I was able to become a little familiar with R.
I learned basic probability and statistics,  hypothesis testing, variables, different methods for linear and multiple regressions, and how to use all of these different topics to analyze data sets.
R coding, some basic stats, economic data analysis
Lots of R, some stats.

Skills:
- Learned to maneuver and analyze data in R
- Developed a strong foundation in statistics 
- Delved deep into theories of causations
- Analyzed real-world occasions and problems
- Applying formulas and material to challenging questions
I learned stats towards Economics as well as very very basic R.
I learned how to code in R.
I learned about linear regressions, kernel regressions, the basics of R, ways to reduce omitted variable bias, hypothesis testing, and probability theory.

The course covers basic statistical tools with a heavy emphasis on practical applications in empirical economic studies. The first part of the course introduces basic probability & statistics mathematics, in the second part (at around the midterm) the emphasis shifts to different models to isolate causality in experiments & studies in economics.
I learned a lot about different regression techniques.
basic knowledge of statistics
This course focuses on learning how to analyze different forms of data through statistical computations using R-Code and algebraic expressions.
Learned basic statistics and tests/experimental methods for causality, learned how to use a little bit of R
statistics, R, econometrics
You get an intro to probability, statistics, econometrics, and coding in R.
Overview course of probability statistics. We did probability theory, hypothesis testing, single and multivariable regressions, difference in difference modeling, and regression discontinuity.
Lots of statistical ability and the ability to read data, not so much actually being able to code.
Learned R and statistics methods. Feel like it was very useful
I learned how to use R (kinda)...

Like the class title says, the basics of statistics and data analysis as it pertains to economics. You learn about the various domains where econometrics is applicable and get to personally try out the econometric methods in various datasets (through R coding software).
Basic overview of statistical concepts as well as several useful experimental designs for economics research (differences in differences, regression discontinuity, instrumental variables)
I learned how to use R as well as topics like linear regression
Pretty jumbled intro to stats but I think they did a good job of teaching basic commands in R
I learned a great deal about the interface between economics and statistics, as well as the programming language R.
Data Analysis and R Skills
We learnt how to code in R and learnt about various methods in statistics to evaluate economic data.

This is an incredible course and after Econ 131 got remorphed into this module, it became amazing! You learn econometrics which is very relevant to the real world and the course teaches you the language R from its basics. Highly highly recommended!

Omg. I learned the absolute minimum by memorizing what the TAs told me. Professor Ryan tries to teach you the theoretical understanding, but does not do it well. You end up having to prove things youve never learned and just memorize what the TAs tell you.
I developed the ability to use data systems and coding.
Regression, very applicable
Great insight into introductory statistics and R
How to use R, statistical methods of analysis

I felt as though I was introduced to the very basics of statistical theory but got a little lost in the later topics of the course. Linear regressions, difference-in-difference, as well as some more basic concepts of variance and covariance that are applicable to the real world but I did not feel like all of these topics were explained well.
I became a better consumer of data and learned how powerful econometrics applications are IRL.
I learned a lot about how to take large sets of economic data and break them down and understand the core aspects of the information.
Statistics and R

The first half of the semester was similar to any Intro Stats course, covering topics from probability to confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. The second half of the semester was more interesting, as we learned about econometric techniques that we can use in research.
Kind of how to use R... also relating probability and statistics to economics.
Use of R and statistics

This course was an introduction to the application of statistical methods to economics. We learned about the basics of probability theory, measures of central tendency, different types of linear regressions, and how to use those concepts in R.
I gained a lot of skills with statistics and working with R.
Learned how to use R with reasonable proficiency. Also, lots of statistics and how stats can be applied to analyze large quantities or economic data.

I developed fundamental knowledge of regression models and how to apply economic concepts to model prediction. The first part of the course laid out the concepts and the second half focused on application.
Knowledge of general econometrics, stats, and R.
Basic statistics and applying these skills to economic data!
You learn about statistical methods relating to economics like probability and regression methods. You learn how to code in R.
Coding in R, statistical analysis skills.

I gained a great knowledge of basic statistical knowledge and data analysis capabilities, along with a working understanding of the basics of R Studio. I feel somewhat empowered to tackle real issues in the world now.
Basic econometric concepts in practice
I learned to code in R, as well as statistics.

This intro Econometrics class taught me most of the skills of basic statistical analysis as well as some of the hallmark tools of applied economic analysis. This was very much an applied class  the theoretical grounding of the class was minimal, and practice and theory were limited as well. Since all psets involved coding in R, I also gained the most basic understanding of coding in R, but anything vaguely complicated or a command that was not explicitly told to us was never used, so I don't feel proficient in it on my own.
Probably the most useful course I have taken so far at Yale--I learned basically everything about introduction to statistics.
I had never known how to use any computer software before this class, very helpful.

This class teaches the topic of econometrics, which is essentially applying statistics and probability to economic topics. The course topics include probability, random variables, running regressions, etc. The coding language used is R, and this class provides the skills to be able to analyze data sets with R (largely through problem sets).
Even though I took AP Stats, I learned a lot more in depth about different statistical tests + models, especially relevant to economics. I also learned some of the foundations of R!

- How to program with R
- The basics of statistics
- worked with interesting data sets

I learned a lot about the importance of statistical methods in economic research. I believe that a better understanding of R and basic data coding interpretation will greatly help me understand economic research papers.
Basic statistics applied to economic settings.
Basic data analysis and probability using the R program.
This course was very helpful in learning standard statistical analysis processes.

I gained the understanding of random variables and the use of different methods to analyze and work with data. From discrete and continuous random variables and their properties (PMF, PDF, CDF, mean, variance, etc) to methods such as non-parametric and linear regressions to difference-in-differences, the course offers a lot of material and dives well into data analysis. The assignments are done in R and mostly well-explained in the instructions alone.
Deeper understanding of econometrics and its applications.
R and Stats.
This course allowed me to learn the fundamentals of data analysis, statistics, and data-driven economics research.
Too difficult and material moves too fast for an intro class course targeted toward underclassmen

If you have previous stats/coding experience, the class is pretty slow for the first three or four weeks. The psets are pretty easy (with the exception of one that is very much based in theory as opposed to programming). The exams were pretty different from the homework, so a lot of people really struggled with it, but the curve makes it so that it's pretty hard to do badly in the class.
I think coding in R is hard, the examinations were hard and the lectures were very pointless.

This course has no strengths. It's weaknesses are many. The goal of the class is to teach students both statistics and how to use R and neither of these things are done well. Professor Ryan speeds through statistical without any explanation and then jumps right into R. Then, the exams are all questions that need to be completed by hand without R. I do not understand how students are supposed to learn how to do these calculations by hand when we have only been taught how to do them in R. With regards to R, although Professor Ryan spends a lot of time showing R outputs to the class and analyzing them, he never actually shows students how to code. I had never coded before this class (it's not a prerequisite) and I literally did not even know what coding was. I had to look everything up online to complete the problem sets. Because students learn nothing in lecture, it is completely useless to go. I went to every lecture and I truly feel my time would have been better spent doing anything other than sitting in this lecture. If lecture is bad, section is worse. In theory, the TA's are supposed to run labs in R with the class. The TA's often do not have the materials and forget how to do things, so most of the class is spent trouble shooting instead of actually learning. In addition, none of the statistical material is covered in section. I'm not sure how learning how to code statistical equations in R is supposed to be useful if we do not even know what the statistical valuations we are coding mean.

Strengths- the content is relevant, TFs were very responsive, problem sets/examples were relevant and helpful, ex: it was cool to evaluate the gender pay gap, race discrimination in the workplace, climate change, etc 
Weaknesses- lecture focuses on theory but we were evaluated on applications... lecture should be more applied, this course draws a competitive bunch that often didn't help one another (or collectively chose to cheat on quizzes, for example), course expectations were often unclear/shifting... ex: due dates for problem sets were moved, TFs often weren't informed on these things, it got confusing
Loved it!
It is so boring omg

Professor Ryan is a great professor, devoted to his students. I felt the material could be dry at times but this may be due to the vast array of notation for slightly differentiated topics. When it comes together, it's pretty nice skillset to acquire. A weakness was the online quiz which encouraged cheating--I felt that penalized students who completed the test honestly.

Strengths: Prof Ryan is a great lecturer, sometimes can get a bit fast but always willing to take a question (although sometimes I wish he wouldn't). He clearly cares about students and wants them to succeed.

Weaknesses: As a fairly new class, some of the scheduling was a little messed up, causing a Pset to be due before we were taught the content of the pset. This was incredibly frustrating and left me discourage with the class some. I think they need to work on their pset/quiz schedule and make a way to make section more useful, because it's utility decreases as the semester went forward.

Strengths: The combination of by hand learning and R makes the class very applicable. The in class case studies made the material a lot more digestible.

Weaknesses: For an introductory course, there was a TON of a material. It was often overwhelming because if I didn't understand something in one lecture then I was lost for the following lectures as well.

This course had well-organized and well-presented lectures. However, I felt as though there was a gap between the class's level of understanding and the expectations of the TFs and professor. While the final exam was very fair, the midterm was insanely difficult compared to the types of problems we had been introduced to in class. Also, in reviews and in section, the TFs would also present information at a level of detail/conceptual difficulty that was often confusing and unnecessary to appreciate the concepts we learned in lecture. That being said, the TFs worked very hard at being available to students during office hours, section, and on Piazza.

Strengths: TA's try to help a fair amount; psets are worth 30%, and you can do well if you just work hard and get help
Weaknesses: so much material, lectures not that easy to understand without prior knowledge

The only redeeming quality of this course was that the lecture slides were comprehensive. Lecture itself was impossible to follow, and Prof. Ryan has a tendency to explain things in the most counterintuitive way possible.

weaknesses: tests much harder than the material explained and the examples show in class - has to be curved a lot, could be more help understanding R in the beginning

strengths: TFs available often during office hours to answer questions, 2 weeks to do each pset was helpful

I thought this course was about as well-run as it could have been. Lectures were by-and-large interesting, filled with case studies and funny comments from Professor Ryan that made the material easier to understand and lectures easier to sit through. The tests were reasonable and there were many practice tests and other test materials to help in review. While the psets were difficult, the TA's did a good job of addressing all questions on Piazza and making them as clear as possible. The material was explained clearly, and I think my only improvement would be to spend more time on the more difficult post-midterm material of regressions, instrumental variables, etc. and maybe move through random variables and expectation functions more quickly.

One major flaw of this course is that the PSETs and class materials do not seamlessly integrate well. The lectures did not really prepare you for the PSETs and the PSETs did not really help in preparing you for the exams. It helps in the sense that you recognize the output format, but besides that, it doesn't really help. The notation in the class is very dense and often hard to understand. Many of the concepts I've learned before in a much more intuitive way, but that sort of insight was not provided by this class because it heavily relied on confusing notation. While learning R was something I was excited to do, I was sick of R by the end of the course especially the times when the Ryan would run code on the screen. It was very hard to follow and did not enhance learning in any way.

Another major flaw of the course is the restriction of calculators during exams. Very simple calculations that would take a matter of seconds on a standard graphing calculator were drawn out to take at least 5 minutes because of the lack of memory on the non-graphing calculators. It leaves a ton of room for error since you have to transcribe and write down every output the calculator gives you before typing in a new calculation. This ends up making the exams difficult, not due to the material, but due to the time constraint and ample room for erroneously writing the wrong number on your paper.

The data we look at this course is very interesting. However, lectures are very confusing and do not help with the problem sets at all. Material seems to be presented in a way much more difficult than it needs to be. Midterms and finals were also pretty difficult and seemed like it didn't give a fair assessment of what we had learned. There also seemed to be some organizational issues, which is to be expected since it was the first time this course had been taught. By and large though, people were generally confused and frustrated in doing the work for this class.

strength: great overview of econometrics, and nice combination of real world cases/working with data and straight theory
weakness: disorganized, theory was poorly taught, and sloppily explained
tests are too hard

Pretty low morale, as past evaluations have pointed out. The lecture slides are enough to study from, but it gets tedious. Emphasis on R is a mistake, as I learned more about coding than econometrics; it should be the other way around, teaching econometrics using R as a tool, not a means.

Strengths:
- well organized to facilitated student learning 
- used current events to help put the importance of the course material in perspective
- professor Ryan facilitated learning -- he was very passionate 

Weaknesses:
- there was not too much practice material to prepare for the exams (though this was likely due to the fact that course was new)
- the PSETS were primarily based in R,  whereas the exams did not have much a focus on that (though I liked this aspect, other students that are more data oriented may have not)
More R can be introduced and less time going over simple concepts.
I didn't feel like I learned about the methodology of solving the mathematical problems in neither lecture nor discussion section. I did a lot of learning on my own outside of class.

The examples that we worked through in class and in problem sets were interesting and meaningful. I liked the combination of learning R as well as the other material. I feel as though the online Quizzes could be improved to better resemble problem sets or exam questions. Also, is it bad that we don't learn Stata? I know that Stata is an industry standard.
The course starts quite simple, which can lead to underestimating the conceptual challenges later on. Apart from that the course was excellent.
It's a pretty good course. I'm annoyed though because I don't think I did well on the final.
a more interactive approach should be taken

Strengths -  lecture is great! The professor teachers very well and class presentations are comprehensive such that you can learn the basics of the material even if you don't go to lecture. Going to lecture really helps to understand all that's going on though so you should probably go.
- We get two weeks to complete each p-set and a online quiz (on-sitting but no time limit) quiz on the weeks when a p-set isn't due. The p-set's are very doable. They consist of a coding portion in R and a written/computational part - the TA's were a great help in doing the homework and understanding the material.

Strengths: organized, useful material
Weaknesses: could be taught in a more intuitive way, would appreciate much more practice with problems and R

It can be improved by posting old midterm or final answers earlier. Students have other tests and lives so you can't just provide practice the night before the exam, please this should be obvious. It can be improved by giving students NOT GRADED practice- quizzes and sets aren't gonna help because they're graded so students must focus on the grade. It is two courses in one- R and stats. The professor teaches with notation/words as if you already know econometrics/stats so it's difficult to learn in lectures. The TAs are very helpful though. There was not much practice at the beginning either and no textbook. The TAs are the only resource to learn which stinks. Or the internet. Lectures were worthless. Once I stopped attending, I started learning more by using the time to google topics instead. ironic.
The strengths were the breadth of material covered, the teaching fellows, and the variety in the data sets. In terms of weaknesses, I think that often grading for problem sets was unclear.

Having average difficulty psets once every two weeks was a nice pace and made the workload pretty chill, so that's a plus. The psets and examples in class also often touched on interesting topics (racism, climate change, female labor force, etc.) so that was a nice way to keep things relevant! The lectures were good and concepts were not too difficult to understand if you put in the time to review them. The only thing is that the exams were pretty different from the practice materials (either in style of question or because 117 covers less than its predecessor version [131] and a lot of 131 material was used as practice materials), which threw us off a bit and was a little annoying.
The class is a little disorganized since you're being taught stats and R at the same time.
Nice to learn R, but they deport explain it enough in class for the level of difficulty of the psets. You're on your own with R.

TERRIBLE - DO NOT RECOMMEND. It is confusing and horribly taught and so time consuming. And the people who have taken Stat before or know R have such an unfair disadvantage all semester long. The TAs are nice though!
More focus on coding in R. Maybe a project in R.
Strength was piazza. Weakness was that it would have been easier to learn if we had been given more practice questions.

There aren't really many examples of problems in the class. I wish we would do less modeling with R in lecture and work out more problems together as a class. I also really didn't like when we would stop the whole lecture for 10 minutes to solve one full problem individually. I'd much rather work through it together as a class.

This course gets you from probability all the way to causal inference. So it is a good intro into the econometric world. A really good strength of this class is the amount of material it has available for practice/preparation for exams. What is a weakness of the course is that sections don't really meet for going over the problem sets until after they are due.

Strengths: Teaching fellows were very helpful during section and office hours 
Weaknesses: Would be helpful to have more emphasis on R coding during lectures

A weakness was lecture. It was impossible to learn anything in lecture, but a strength was that office hours were very helpful. Office hours were necessary, but if you played a sport, it was impossible to attend putting who played one at a huge disadvantage.

Nick is an ok lecturer, but I think there were multiple times when people had no idea what was happening and he just decided to keep going.  I also think we should be tested on more R skills - maybe a takehome final or something.
The PSETs did not really correlate well with what we were learning. The exams had extreme time pressure.

Professor Ryan is the best lecturer that I have had this far into my Yale education. The level of detail on his slides is impeccable, and his enthusiasm for the course material clearly shows every class.
More office hours

We had just one review session for our final exam and it took place the night before our final. Lectures could have been more helpful and Professor Ryan could have taken more time explaining concepts.

Strengths: you learn econometrics relevant to the real world and you come out with a great understanding of how interesting economics is when looking at the data. You also end up learning the language R which is probably the  most useful program!

Pretty much all weaknesses. The course is new and it seems Professor Ryan didnt think through WHY we learn things. We skim over so much material just to learn things well completely disregard later. Another weakness is that the problem sets are SO skewed because everyone just goes to office hours and asks the TAS for the answers. This is so necessary bc you wouldnt know how to do anything otherwise, but it means you dont learn anything.
It was hard to follow the course material and it was pretty confusing to put everything together. Not enough applicable examples on how to do things.
Very hard, didnt like R that much.
Strengths were definitely the TAs and problem sets. Weakness was exam preparation.

Strengths were that communication between students, instructors, and TAs was sufficient and helped a lot with problem sets and test questions. The lecture slides were also very useful and provided a good resource for review. Weaknesses were that the class oftentimes moved too quickly and sometimes topics were not explained in enough detail or in ways that made sense. There were never enough practice problems that resembled the ones we received on the test.
PowerPoint slides were helpful and professor was great. We spent too much time going over code in class without learning what the code did which was unhelpful.

All of the TAs dont speak English very well which is a downside but they do try their best and I commend them for their effort. The professor has a hard time simplifiying the material which can occasionally make the topics more confusing then they need to be
One of the worst courses at Yale, only take if u have to
I liked how the class used real research papers as examples to illustrate concepts we learned in lecture.

Should have spent more time in the beginning teaching students how to use R since we used it for every problem set. Those unfamiliar with R were greatly disadvantaged to those who had computer science backgrounds or backgrounds in probability and statistics.

Strengths - very pragmatic approach to solutions and problems. Grading was very fair and feedback was great. Sections were also very useful
Weakness - the lectures were very boring and were hard to follow

I liked that we got to use real world data in our problem sets, so we could see early-on how the skills we were learning were applicable. But I think overall, the class was somewhat disorganized. We would jump back and forth between theory and R-code and working out examples by hand, so it would often be hard to follow what was happening during lecture. I think this got better after the midterm, but especially at the beginning of the semester, lecture moved very quickly and jumped between topics.

The lectures were very slow, which helped to learn some of the concepts better upon first seeing them, but it also made it easy to get distracted. While the R samples in class were helpful at times, they were difficult to follow along.

Strengths: Clear lecture slides, everything is posted so you can review if you dont understand. Lots of office hours if you need help. Weaknesses: pretty long psets. Sometimes a bit above the information given in class, so they can take some going through outside resources. Definitely have a pset buddy! Exams are incredibly hard.

The course was fantastic at teaching fundamental concepts of probability, random variables, and model building for data analysis. While the lecture material was easy to follow and well-organized, I feel as though the problem sets focused too much on practicing and teaching R and not enough on applying the concepts from lecture. Thus, when it came time for exams, I felt unprepared to solve the problems.
Section, lectures and psets tended to differ somewhat.
I thought it was a very well-taught course. The TAs were absolutely amazing and very invested, which was crucial to the success of the course.

The main strength was that the course structure is strong and covers a good balance between theory and application. The main weakness was that the midterm and final were pretty poorly structured and while the TAs picked up some of the slack, Professor Ryan did not do a great job a) writing the exam (specifically the midterm) b) engaging students with any sort of resources.

Having never taken a statistics course before, I found myself thrust into an intro stats course designed for people who sorta already knew how to do things but wanted a refresher, like someone who took ap stats junior year of high school and never touched it since. The plus side of this is that the course was fast paced and covered a lot of great material. The downside was that, for someone like me, it was incredibly challenging. 
I feel like the course had a good trajectory from start to end, everything we learned following logically from a gap in the previous thing we learned. This is something  I only recognize in hindsight, but nevertheless well done. 
I feel like the R side of the class was pretty inadequately taught. There was never any real guidance besides "here's a function, use it". The course is advertised as no coding experience required, which I think is a blatant fiction. Having a basic understanding of coding syntax is essential, and it was incredibly challenging to grasp right off the bat. 
Furthermore, the grading on psets seems a little weird. It looks like only specific questions on every pset are actually graded, with large portions of it being ignored. Not only does this lead to an inadequate reflection of my knowledge, but it also means I don't get feedback on the whole pset, so I don't know if I did it right or not. 
Overall, I think the course needs improving, but as it's a new course that's understandable. I think, given a few years, this could grow to be one of the best courses at Yale, purely based on its content and course arc.
Strengths are that plenty of real econometric papers and datasets are used, though the exams are suddenly a lot harder than usual assignments.
There was little room to practice and learn. It would be helpful if lecture was more engaging and there were more practice problems throughout the course.

The design of the course is great in practice. It assumes no prior knowledge of any statistics or coding. But realistically, expectations were extremely unclear. The problem sets were due every other week in R, and often times were not directly related to the theory we learned. We zoomed past the theory; that was fine, given that you really needed only the "what"  the end formula, the definition in problem sets, but often on tests we were tested deeply on the theoretical stuff. This would have been fine if expectations were clear, and if there was ample and relevant practice/past tests, but in the both in the midterm and the final that was not the case. The strength of the class was definitely the data sets we used. A ton of high-profile and big-name data sets were used in problem sets, and if you're at all interested in the conclusions of some of the major, major economic studies of our time and how people got there (Raj Chetty on inequality, for example), some of the problem sets will actually be a treat.

Since this was the first time that this course was ever run, it is understood that it would have some flaws. Although I believe that the course in its entirety was well structured, most of the topics that were featured failed to be fully explained and developed. For example we spent only two lectures on a concept as basic as hypothesis testing. I felt that sometimes the professor did not fully realize the workload that he assigned as. Even tough most of the problem sets were pretty easy and helped us to apply the concepts that we learned very well, a few of them (mainly referring to problem set 5) were extremely hard for no particular reason. This had as a result for some students to just directly copy the answers from the Teaching Assistants, and then the rest of the students just to copy off their answers from these few, since literally no one was able to figure out the particular exercises. I felt like problem sets like these caused us more stress and hardship instead of helping us learn anything new. Despite the above, the TAs were all stellar and very helpful although I would have preferred to see more native English speakers, because some times I had difficulty understanding what they were saying. Finally, I really appreciated the generous curves of the final and midterms.
Slower pace--as someone who has never taken any stats before, I found it somewhat overwhelming!
I think that the relationship between the p sets and exams needs to be better.

The strengths are that the class provides great exposure to the topics required for an understanding of econometrics. Furthermore, it goes as far as explaining the fundamentals of model building and fitting for data analysis, with the hopes of not only understanding what's going on but imparting the tools for further data exploration. The weaknesses are that R is not taught very thoroughly, and is rather a teach-yourself sort of thing. The TAs do a good job of walking through it, but it requires going to a lot of office hours. Having prior coding experience is definitely a plus.

Strengths: Applicable in teaching us R, gets pretty interesting because we can work with data related to real life issues (race and education, maternal mortality rates, etc). Piazza is a huge help!
Weaknesses: Psets are ass sometimes (can take several hours, especially with theory portions), and quizzes are unnecessarily tricky. TAs aren't that helpful in person.

Strengths: Prof Ryan is generally a good lecturer; exam material is representative of what is on the exams
Weaknesses: We don't learn a lot of important conceptual ideas behind the formulas that are thrown around in lecture; this is very dangerous because exams often involve applying formulas which one cannot do if one doesn't understand the concept behind the formulas; for example i learned how to apply a third of the material we covered in class from a friend in the few hours before the final exam

The course strength lies in how it allows students to engage in materials outside of pure economic theory. The lectures have many examples from recent economic researches that emphasize the theoretical concepts being in covered in an introductory course. The course also has a lot of available help from TFs and was taught at a slower pace than normal. I think the course could be improved by having better psets that are more relevant to the tests. The course syllabus could also follow a textbook to make it easier for students to have independent studying.

Strength was that it taught skills that are useful in the real world, such as coding and data analysis. Weakness was that the lectures could be explained more thoroughly. Could be improved through better walkthroughs in lecture and section.
I think we did not spend enough time learning R.

A strength of the course is the great instructor, Professor Nicholas Ryan, and his team of TFs. They were very helpful when it comes to clarifying material and providing assistance on problem sets and in review sessions. The material in the course can be confusing at times and the support provided to students is excellent. The course is also organized in a well-fashioned and cumulative manner, in which each lecture builds off of the previous. A weakness of the course could be the timing of the quiz and assignment due dates, sometimes they overlapped on the same week and it seemed as if the individual difficulties of each assignment were not considered when setting up quiz schedule.

Strengths: Highly engaged teaching fellows, highly applicable subject matter, questions in lecture good 

Weaknesses: Slightly dry lectures, PSets not as flexible

I think that the course needs to either have pre requisites, or it should try to cover less. For someone who had no background in either R or Statistics, it was very difficult to keep up with the pace of the class.

Strengths: It provides an excellent background on randomized control trials - an experimental method used across industries including academic, policy, private-sector. The course is also good for students interested in data-driven decision making.
Only if you are an econ major

I think this course is a great introduction to data analysis, but if you've already taken another class like Stat230 of 361 it probably won't be that helpful. There's a little bit of theory that you don't get in those courses, though.
R is hard, but you have to take it to fulfill the requirement.
Absolutely not. If there is any other way you can fulfill the econometrics requirement for the econ major do it. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.

This was a very challenging course. I'd recommend it to a student interested in having a good background in statistics, but they should be prepared to be organized and work hard. I personally think the content is extremely relevant, though, as we looked at some of the major policy issues of our time from an evidence-based, quantitative lens.

A great class to take if you have only focused on the theoretical side of economics as this introduces you to the empirical side. Especially useful if you foresee yourself wanting to write a senior thesis.
I would only recommend this course to another student if they were an economics major and were trying to fulfill the econometrics requirement.
no, but its a prereq
Don't take this unless you have to for your Econ major. Definitely my least favorite Econ class I've taken at Yale and the exams were difficult and time-intensive.
Interesting course. Very technical. Be prepared for a torrent of formulas and concepts.

I would definitely recommend it to everyone, even if you aren't an Econ major, take it Credit/D! You will walk out feeling confident about your ability to look at data, even if the exams and psets hurt a little.
The material is definitely useful and applicable, but I do not know that I would recommend it.
I would because you learn fundamental skills of economic analysis, but I would wait a few semesters until there are sufficient practice materials from the new iteration of the course.
If you have to take it, work hard and you'll be fine. Otherwise, don't take it

Only take this course if you need to take it. The PSETs dont really test your knowledge of the material, and really just focus on using R to conduct statistical analysis. The exams dont test R knowledge so there is no point to the PSETs, as they arent really conducive to learning the statistical theory under the code.
No unless it was required for their major and they had to take it

I would recommend this class, especially to economics or statistics majors but really anybody can benefit from this class. The class starts at the basics and moves its way up pretty smoothly, so no matter what your starting understanding of statistics or data analysis is you can pick up the material easily. The material itself is really fascinating in my opinion, and by the end of the class I feel I have not only a practical understanding of regressions and other causation methods, but a working understanding of the coding language R as well.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, whether or not they are an economics major, because it allows you to develop extremely useful skills for both other courses and the post-grad work.
I would not recommend this course. The course was heavily a statistics course with almost no integration with economics. With that said, I think other stats courses are taught better.
If you're an economics major, then yes. Otherwise probably not. Not a terrible course but takes a bit to get the hang of.
only within the economics major
Take it only if required to. Otherwise no.

I would recommend this course to any students that are talented with math and want to learn statistics. This course is especially good for those interested in data analysis, but have no previous experience. This class is more challenging than an introductory statistics course, however I believe that you learn much more.
It's a requirement for the Econ major, so my hands are tied there.

If you're considering this class, you're an Econ major, so you have to take it. You learn R, so that's useful, but the class gets old pretty quickly. Exams seemed pretty tough, but apparently this is better than Econ 131 (the old version) used to be, so that's good, I guess?
I would recommend this to any Econ major (you need to take this course).

Yes, I would easily recommend this course to other students. The second half of the course was incredibly interesting, with Prof. Ryan talking through statistical methods in the context of real papers, which more often than not provided unique insights into the world around us. Especially in this part of the course, I left every lecture realizing I had learned something new about the world.
I mean it's a pre-req so yah I guess. Lowkey salty that I always get screwed by the curve lol.

Yes, I have no major complaints about this class. It was great to learn how to use R-code to analyze data which is very useful if you want to know how to conduct research and have statistically proven results/outcomes. We got to analyze many different topics in class using the tools learned such as what causes the wage gap between men and women, how education affects a person's future earnings and more.
Only if you have to for econ major
only if you need it for the major
It's probably a requirement so yes.
Yep, a pretty chill and fair introduction to stats/R!
I don't know if it's better than the other econometrics courses.
Only take it if you need to. Definitely better than what 130 used to be.

TERRIBLE - DO NOT RECOMMEND. It is confusing and horribly taught and so time consuming. And the people who have taken Stat before or know R have such an unfair disadvantage all semester long. The TAs are nice though!
Yes -  I think it's a  great way to learn statistics even if you are not an econ major.
Yes. Super useful for anyone interested in analysis.
It's an econ requirement...I just hope they make it a little better.
If you plan to measure in economics, then obviously. Even so, it isn't so bad of a course to try out if you are willing to put in the work and struggle a bit.
yes
Yes, very helpful for future economics electives and research
I would only recommend this course if its necessary for your major.

Big Yike. You prob have to take it for Econ, so get ready to spend a lot of time in office hours. The issue is that there will be people who have all the stats knowledge in the world taking this course, and so if you have no stats knowledge you have to work pretty hard. You can do well, but it's a lot of effort - def take it on a 4 credit semester.

I cannot recommend this course. The tests focus on subject matter that is completely different than the p-sets and biweekly quizzes. Further, the TAs seem generally underprepared (with the exception of the head TA) to answer meaningful questions during section. Preparation for tests is inadequate.  There are hardly any application-based exercises to speak of for homework, whereas the midterm and final are comprised entirely of application-based scenarios. Finallythis cannot be stressed enough with so much coding in the p-sets which count for 30% of the grade  (and, mind you, the R coding language was NOT ONCE mentioned in a question on the final), all students should take a prerequisite course in some sort of coding language (preferably R). This course is basically a glorified statistics course and you dont need to take a primer course for this part, but the R coding language will definitely rock your world every second and fourth Thursday of the month when you stay up all night scratching your head about why a code doesnt work (and why your TA and Professor have the expectation that you should know how to troubleshoot code issues without ever having a background in it).
Not really, but its required for the major.
I would recommend this course to another student. It was a little difficult for an intro course, but I feel like I learned a lot about econometrics and statistics.
One of the best economics courses I took at Yale. If you want to learn the basics of econometrics and how it relates to the real world, this is the course for you.
NO. Absolutely the worst class Ive taken at Yale. The DUS should strongly reconsider how this course is taught and the level of engagement required from the Professor.
Only if it is necessary for your major.
Necessary for Econ majors.
Yes. Its a requirement and Professor Ryan does a good job teaching this course.
Would definitely recommend this course. It's very insightful and the professor is genuinely interested in the material. You'll become a better consumer of data and it'll be helpful in the future.
I most definitely would recommend this course to another student. It gives students a great introductory insight into economic analysis go about break down larger data sets
No. Nick Ryan is terrible, class is terrible
Yes, I think it's useful. But, I do think the class is more challenging if you come from a background with zero knowledge of statistics or R.
Probably not unless you already know what you're doing.
Yes

I would probably not recommend this course (except if required for the econ major). If you're just interested in learning about intro stats, you would probably be better served by a class in another department. The lecture in this class was just hard to follow and didn't really prepare us for the psets or the exams, so I'd say skip it if you don't need it for the major.
I would recommend this course to another student. As someone with no coding experience, this class was very helpful without ever being overwhelming.
Only if you need it as a major requirement. You definitely develop great skills in stats and build a strong base in using R. Takes a lot of time though and can be really challenging at times.

I would absolutely recommend this course to students who like to see practical applications of statistics and data analysis to real-world case studies. It was also a great introduction to the R programming language.
Yes--great for understanding economics.
Yes! Only if you haven't taken statistics before though  otherwise, it may be a bit easy.
If you need the class for the major then sure. If you want to learn about statistics more broadly you may want to take intro stats.
Yes, if you're an Econ major. Otherwise, there are better statistics courses.

This is an important course to take for econ majors like myself, and I'm glad I took it. I'm planning on taking it's successor course next semester.
If you're an outside looking in, here's my advice: If you truly have no understanding of statistics or coding and want to get into it, consider an intro stats course like 101 the base level, and this like the honors course. Know that it will be challenging and you will have to work your ass off, as you'll be competing with people who already know all the material taught in the first half of this semester.
Not until it is better facilitated.

If you're an economics major, this is basically a required course. I benefitted greatly from a little bit of a statistical background (high school) and found that it made the first half of the course, on which the second is grounded, significantly theoretically easier. It's possible to do well in this course without actually understanding the underlying theory, but if you're interested in that this is not the class for you.

I mean, if you have to take it for the econ major, try to get Vitor as your TA--he is one of the best humans I have ever met and am so grateful to have been his student. He devotes endless patience and energy to his students and if you want to do well, he will match your level to devotion and help you succeed.
I would, it's highly applicable.

I'd definitely recommend this class, as it grants you the tools to analyze a lot of questions that are often posed--questions relating to wage gap, whether race plays a role in job hiring, impact of temperature on crop yield, etc. It feels very fulfilling to walk out knowing you could build your own model to analyze a data set and draw conclusions.

Probably wouldn't recommend this outside of if you need to take it for your major. It's not the worst, kinda interesting/less theoretical than the intro/intermediate micro and macro sequences. I do recommend you take at least one stats course in your time at Yale, since you'll need these skills no matter where you go in the future. Econometrics is good just because it teaches you R, but I do realize that at the end of this course, I still only have a pretty elementary grasp of data science.

i would recommend this course to anyone interested in gaining an overview of statistics- not a conceptually enlightening review of statistics. if you just want to learn R- there are other courses for that. if you just want to learn stats- there are also other courses for that. Avoid this course unless you must take it.
Yes, but only because econometrics is required for economics major.
It is good for basic coding skills but they do not teach you how to code. They drop you in the deep end and you either learn or drop.

I would certainly recommend this course to students studying Economics and even to those studying other social sciences, as the methods of understanding and working with data is excellently taught in this course.
Yes - econometrics/data analysis is very applicable and Professor Ryan is an effective instructor!

I would only recommend it if you need it for the major. It was difficult and not too interesting. I also recommend either learning R or taking an intro Stats class beforehand, because it is difficult to keep up with the class with no background in either.
I highly recommend the course to all students interested in development economics, data analysis, evidence-based decision making.
